ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned basic concepts in quantitative and population genetics and how to calculate (by hand) various metrics to describe/simplify the biological world.
evolutionary genetics concepts, techniques, calculations, current research, connections to society
I learned many skills and tests for research in the field of evolutionary genetics.
many methods to take genetic data as an input and interpret things about organisms' evolutionary histories!
Review of Mendelian genetics, introductions to both population genetics and quantitative genetics, and practice in writing for grant proposals.
I learned a great deal about quantitative and population genetics and the ways in which scientists study them.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Prof Coughlan is a great lecturer, inspiring scientist, and warm person. The class was very well structured and I was able to get excited about new topics.

This course was fantastic. I left with concrete skills and concepts that I can apply to my research. The material was taught to a high level and so much effort was taken so every student would leave the course at that high level, which happened which is very rare. I appreciated the variety of work, including a mock grant and discussions about how the context relates to societal problems. This is not a standard for STEM classes, but should be. The strength of this course really is Professor Coughlan, who is one of the best professors I have had.

I think this course had to cover a lot of information, and sometimes it became too fast for me to understand what was happening. I know that my peers were also struggling at some points during the semester just because of the pace.
the lecture content was suuuper interesting but not always explained in the clearest way

The course was very engaging and I learned a lot of both theory and practical skills in the lecture. The few required readings were very applicable to the lecture material and it didnt feel like it was redundant.

Professor Coughlan and Hagar were both strengths for this course. I took the class because I thought the material would be useful for me, not because I had a particularly strong personal interest in the material ahead of time. Professor Coughlan's lectures were interesting and engaging, and they made me genuinely enjoy and invest in the material much more than I thought I would. I really appreciated the balance between lectures as well as occasional readings, discussions, and projects, all of which helped increase my engagement with the material. I also really liked the way our assignments were structured -- the weekly problem sets were not too time consuming, but they were well designed to make me actually review and learn the material better each week (a rare example of me actually liking and appreciating problem sets), and the combination of two exams as well as a grant proposal project made the class less stressful than if it had had more exams. 

I think the biggest suggestion I had would be to change the lecture slides a bit. I often had a hard time finding the lectures on canvas when I wanted to review, because the way they were labeled didn't always make it clear what material would be covered in each slideshow. Also, while I found the lectures engaging during class, they often moved very quickly, and especially in the second half of the semester I had a hard time keeping up with the material during class. I wish the lectures posted to canvas afterwards included answers to the practice problems posed in class as well as explanations of the figures, as I sometimes struggled to keep up with note-taking enough to remember what had been said about the practice problems and figures during class.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! I'm not an E&EB major but I learned so much new and interesting content from this course and always looked forward to it.
Yes. If you are E&EB this class is essential. You learn so much and it is enjoyable.
I would recommend this course to anyone studying evolutionary biology or evolutionary genetics because the course is very helpful for developing an understanding of experiments for research.
Yes. I would recommend this course to anyone who enjoyed evolutionary biology.
I would recommend this class to E&EB majors looking for a relatively challenging upper level class that will greatly understand their knowledge of genetic testing and research.
